the obvious problems why it didn't work:

- power was cut, so it already had spun down significantly and when it then got stopped on impact, it couldn't spin back up again
- there was a fat metal bolt in the wood which prevented the sawblade digging into the wood in the first place
- the guideline for the saw wasn't set up very well. for a good result, I think rails would work much better because of better control over the trajectory
- the rocket explosion really messed up the most important moment, just because of this another try would have been nice

Was anyone actually expecting this to work? The rate-limiting step in sawing with a circular saw is not at all how fast you push the saw linearly through the wood. If they could get the blade itself to rotate faster (rockets attached to augment the spinning blade perhaps?), then maybe you can increase the maximum cutting rate, which allows the saw to be effectively pushed faster. The cutting rate is also a function of the properties of the wood, and the width of the blade, the sharpness of the blade, the material properties of the blade, etc.

1: I have that battery powered Ryobi circular saw, and it's not very good. I had trouble cutting a sheet of 3/4" OSB with it a few years ago. this experiment was destined (pun not intended) for "failure" (the saw not cutting the wood in any significant way)

2: your test rig had WAY too much play in it for the saw to ever make real contact. that saw hit and bounced, I'm surprised the blade even made the gouges it did. I think we both know you need proper rails and not just cables for this. you need a solid rail and roller system, which you could fabricate for about $100 in parts from home depot, and would probably be very useful to have for motion-based projects anyway. it's a great way to make sure a fast moving object moves across the high-speed camera frame properly.

3: as others have mentioned, there was a serious lack of safety concern here, besides the fact that you were making a rocket saw.
A: no eye protection.
B: fingers waaaaay too close to a spinning blade at 2:46
C: there was no real need for your running jump at 2:53 . slow down and be careful. you're dealing with things that could very easily hurt you.
D: no "don't try this at home" disclaimer. come on, you're a professional at this stuff, and you KNOW someone's going to try this now.

4: IT'S NOT SCIENCE IF YOU DON'T DOCUMENT YOUR FINDINGS! The edited entertainment-style video does not count as documenting your findings. and regardless of whether you planned to feed the computer the data, you still should have left it with the sensor array and showed us what happened on impact as far as the motion sensors. I saw the blade spin backward in the high speed, which was interesting, and I'd have liked to see the spikes on the accelerometers when the motor got the blade spinning the right way again.

I knew the saw was only going to leave a series of notches on the board in advance, you need a metal pipe above with a notch cut through the wall, the full length of the pipe, and a section of smaller diameter pipe to fit into it with clearance, and a section of flat stock steel as a spacer to provide clearance for the long pipe wall thickness (small pipe to saw, welded).  You also need to appropriately countersink and bevel the needed leading edges of inside and outside of pipes to guide the one into another, and if it still bobs around, attach other pipe sections to the side of saw.  You'll need a framework to secure or weld the pipe to it.

Another interesting edge case to add would be a dragster saw.  You could use the same guidewire setup you used for the rocket saw.  Instead of using the rocket to propel the saw use a long drag strip made of 2x6s and let the saw propel itself along the track guided by your guidewire setup.  The saw will want to ride up out of the wood, so its behavior may vary depending upon how heavily it is weighted.  The acceleration will most probably trigger the safety stop.  The interesting edge case would be the one where the guidewire or the weighting was adjusted so as not to trigger a stop.

I have to remark on the paradigm I have here. I used to be a teacher. If you want to have a kid really learn how to do something, gamify it. Kids' natural learning process is play - it's how we pick up virtually all of our healthy social-emotional skills. It is from this viewpoint that I have to wonder at the "Adults" doing "very important" "learning" by playing in the most fantastically adult way I can imagine: strapping rockets to a circular saw and watching it wreck into a 4x4 with several thousand dollars worth of high-speed camera.
